to verritas: To mount the image, download a mounting program. A good one is here: http://www.poweriso.com/download.htm
1. Download that program.
2. Install the program.
3. Open program and mount the proper file.
4. Open the mounted file (it will be in My Computer) as a CD Disc. 
Hope that helps.

 Just like to add a bit of info on a tip given in the comments.

 Daemon tools can mount and read any disc image format.

 All you need to do is while looking for the file to mount, goto the drop down menu the corner and select "All supported images".

 You'll be able to see and select it to mount then.

Fun little game, runs perfectly. Thanks FuCtUpPuNk.

If any of you are getting that stupid c+ runtime error try re-downloading the c+ runtime libraries or making sure you have all your windows updates done as you get them that way too. You can also try installing an older version of Direct X like 9.0c as some games need the older files from it as new computers don't have a few bits from 9 and before in their newer DX packages! May sort it out for you if you haven't fixed it already! when i tried to start the game it says not a win32 valid application. I followed the instructions you've said

Daemon tools doesn't deal with .bin alone,, you just have to create a.cue file with this :
FILE "EXEMPLE.BIN" BINARY
TRACK 01 MODE1/2352
INDEX 01 00:00:00 

where EXEMPLE.BIN is the exact path of the .bin file, in that case : torchlight.bin.

Done.

sorry but when i wrote this comment^ i hadn't actually downloaded the torrent so i figured that it would be simple.Just forget i wrote the above.

i "quote" brittton 27:

It's really simple, treat the .bin file, which is the bulk of the data in this torrent, as a compressed archive like a .zip or .rar file. I used a program called AlZip to unpack the bin into its own folder. It dumps out yet another torchligh.bin file which you again extract to the same folder your already in. Then it will list out the files that your looking for, the setup, autorun, etc.

Why the uploaded didn't just make an ISO to mount is beyond me. I think you can mount a bin file with Daemon tools but I've never tired it.

I tried this on XP SP2 32bit and it worked fine, if your Daemon tools or Power ISO doesn't detect the image when you try to mount it, just select "Show All" in the file type drop down box and double click the bin file anyway, still works
